title-group.article-title: Uncovering the genetic landscape of soybean accessions from Kazakhstan in comparison with global germplasm using whole genome resequencing

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Soybean (Glycine max) is a globally important crop, yet its genetic diversity remains underutilized in breeding programs, particularly in emerging production regions such as Kazakhstan. As Kazakhstan expands its soybean cultivation, a detailed understanding of the genetic diversity and population structure of both local and international germplasm is critical for developing regionally adapted cultivars.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: This study analyzed 694 soybean accessions – including landraces, modern cultivars, and wild relatives (Glycine soja) – using 80,971 high-quality SNPs obtained via whole-genome resequencing. Population structure analysis, PCA, and phylogenetic clustering consistently distinguished wild from cultivated groups and identified transitional genotypes bridging the two. Kazakhstan’s accessions showed closest genetic similarity to European and North American cultivars, reflecting historical cultivar exchange and breeding for temperate adaptation. However, Kazakhstan’s accessions exhibited the lowest within-group diversity, underscoring a narrow genetic base.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: These findings reveal the genetic structure and evolutionary relationships within a global soybean collection and highlight the limited genetic diversity of Kazakhstan’s germplasm. The results suggest two complementary breeding strategies for Kazakhstan: (1) broadening the genetic base through the introduction of diverse foreign and wild germplasm, and (2) increasing the frequency of favorable alleles already present in locally adapted lines. This integrated approach can support the development of high-performing, resilient cultivars tailored to Kazakhstan’s agricultural environments.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12864-025-12024-8.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Soybean [Glycine max (L.) Merr.] is one of the key legume crops and a primary source of protein and oil for human consumption, animal feed, and industrial applications [1]. As of 2024, the leading soybean-producing countries are Brazil, the USA, and Argentina [2]. Kazakhstan is rapidly increasing its soybean cultivation. Over the past decade, soybean production in Kazakhstan has seen substantial growth. In 2011, approximately 71,000 hectares were dedicated to soybeans; by 2021, this area had expanded to over 200,000 hectares. The climate in Kazakhstan restricts suitable cultivation areas, but irrigation has enabled yields to reach up to 5.5 tons per hectare. The primary soybean-producing regions in Kazakhstan are the Almaty region, which contributes 83% of the production, followed by East Kazakhstan at 9.4%, and Kostanay at 3.9% (www.stat.gov.kz). The country is focusing on developing new soybean cultivars with high productivity, protein, and oil content to adapt to its diverse soil and climatic conditions [3–5].

With the growing focus on the collection, evaluation, and utilization of soybean germplasms in the world, significant efforts have been made to uncover the genetic structure and diversity of soybean cultivars, landraces, and wild soybean germplasms. It is suggested that soybeans have spread from East Asia (China) to various regions of Asia, where numerous landraces and local cultivars were developed [6]. Hymowitz and Kaizuma (1981) [6], through an analysis of the Kunitz trypsin inhibitor (Ti) and the beta-amylase isozyme (Sp1 = Amy3), identified seven soybean germplasm pools in Asia: (1) northeast China and the ex-USSR, (2) central and south China, (3) Korea, (4) Japan, (5) Taiwan and South Asia, (6) northern India and Nepal, and (7) central India. These regions form the secondary gene centers of soybeans, indicating areas where soybeans were cultivated and diversified after their initial domestication. They also suggested that the soybeans from the Asian part of ex-USSR came from northeast China [6]. The other study surveyed 1005 G. max and 258 Glycine soja Siebold & Zucc. (wild soybean) accessions of the USDA soybean germplasm collection using 13 isozyme loci [7]. They found that the G. max accessions from southeast Asia stood out from those from the other group of origin. They also suggested that the accessions in the latter maturity groups represented a distinct population from those in the earlier maturity groups [7]. However, these studies utilized a limited number of molecular markers.

Modern DNA markers are crucial for analyzing plant genetic diversity, facilitating the assessment of genetic variation, population structure, and relationships among cultivars and their wild relatives [8]. While earlier marker systems, such as AFLP and RFLP, played a foundational role, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) now dominate due to their abundance, genome-wide distribution, and suitability for high-throughput, large-scale analyses [9, 10]. SNPs are widely applied in genetic linkage mapping, genome-wide association studies (GWAS), and genomic selection, significantly advancing crop improvement programs.

Technological advancements in SNP genotyping – ranging from the SoySNP50K array [11] to high-density platforms like the Axiom® SoyaSNP array [12] – have revolutionized soybean genomics by enabling comprehensive characterization of genetic diversity across global germplasm collections. High-throughput methods, such as the Infinium BeadChip assay [11] and genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) [13], along with whole-genome resequencing (WGRS), now enable the identification of millions of genome-wide variants. These approaches have facilitated in-depth analyses of quantitative trait loci (QTLs), adaptive variation, and population structure [14–16].

Analyzing population structure and genetic variability in diverse crop populations provides valuable insights into their evolutionary history, the selection pressures they face, and the genetic makeup essential for modern breeding programs. Understanding these genetic relationships enables breeders to optimize their strategies, minimize inbreeding, maximize diversity, and effectively utilize local germplasm to select desirable traits such as disease resistance and yield [17–19]. Furthermore, accounting for population structure in GWAS analysis is crucial to prevent false positives and identify genuine genetic markers for desired traits [20–21].

Building on these advances, the present study employs a WGRS-based high-density SNP panel to investigate the genetic diversity and population structure of a global soybean collection. By integrating G. max accessions from Kazakhstan with international G. max and G. soja germplasm, this analysis aims to elucidate the genetic history and evolutionary relationships of local varieties of G. max.

sec.title: Plant materials
sec.p: A total of 694 soybean accessions were analyzed in this study, comprising 534 modern cultivars, 66 G. max landraces, and 94 G. soja accessions (Table S1). The germplasm collection was assembled from two main sources: one group of 252 accessions, including 31 cultivars and breeding lines from Kazakhstan, previously established by our team [22]; and the remaining accessions, which were obtained from the Department of Life Sciences at Guangzhou University, China. For analytical purposes, the entire collection was categorized into seven groups based on geographic origin and taxonomic status: Europe (211 genotypes), East Asia (n = 145), North America (n = 96), South America (n = 51), Kazakhstan (n = 31), landraces from China (n = 66), and wild accessions (G. soja, n = 94) (Fig. S1).

sec.title: Resequencing of studied collection
sec.p: WGRS was performed using the Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform. Library preparation was performed using the Illumina TruSeq DNA Sample Preparation Kit, according to the manufacturer’s protocol. In total, 252 soybean accessions were newly sequenced in this study [23], while resequencing data for an additional 442 accessions were obtained from the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under the following accession numbers: SRP469369, SRP114890, SRP250886, SRP387668, SRP326758, and SRP344122 [24–29].

Paired-end sequencing reads were aligned to the soybean reference genome (Glycine max Wm82.a2.v1), available at SoyBase [30], using the Burrows-Wheeler Aligner (BWA) [31]. Post-alignment processing included realignment around insertions and deletions (indels) using the IndelRealigner module in GATK version 4 [32]. Variant calling for single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and indels was conducted using both GATK and SAMtools version 1.4 [33], ensuring high-confidence variant detection across the genome.

SNP VCF files from multiple studies were merged using VCFtools [34], resulting in a dataset containing 8,319,433 SNPs. To generate a computationally manageable dataset for downstream analyses, the VCF file was annotated based on the reference genome using ANNOVAR software [35], and synonymous mutations within coding regions were extracted, yielding 183,945 SNPs. Synonymous SNPs are generally considered selectively neutral, making them suitable for capturing underlying neutral population structure without confounding effects of selection [36– 37]. Further filtering was applied to retain SNPs with less than 10% missing data and a minor allele frequency (MAF) greater than 5%. After filtering, a final dataset of 80,971 high-quality SNPs was obtained.

sec.title: Allelic pattern and analysis of molecular variance
sec.p: Genetic diversity indices – including the number of different alleles (Na), number of effective alleles (Ne), observed heterozygosity (Ho), expected heterozygosity (He), and Shannon’s information index (I) – were estimated using PLINK version 1.9 [38]. To assess population structure and differentiation, additional evolutionary parameters were calculated. Pairwise genetic differentiation between groups was estimated using Wright’s fixation index (FST); nucleotide diversity (π), Watterson’s theta (θ), and Tajima’s D test were computed to evaluate levels of polymorphism within populations using VCFtools. These analyses were performed using VCFtools and custom R scripts, and they provide a comprehensive view of genetic variation, differentiation, and evolutionary dynamics across the collection. Analysis of molecular variance (AMOVA) was also conducted to partition genetic variation within and among populations using the poppr package in R version 4.3.3 [39].

sec.title: Population genetic analyses and clustering
sec.p: The following analyses were performed using two distinct datasets: the entire collection of 694 accessions, comprising both G. max and G. soja, and a subset consisting of 600 G. max accessions only. Principal component analysis (PCA) based on genetic distances was performed using the genetics and snpStats packages in R version 4.3.3. Population structure was evaluated using a model-based Bayesian approach implemented in STRUCTURE version 2.3.4 [40]. This analysis involved four independent runs for each value of K (ranging from 1 to 10), with each run comprising 100,000 Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) iterations following a burn-in of 100,000 iterations. No prior information regarding the origin of accessions was used. The optimal number of clusters (K) was determined using CLUMPAK, based on the log probability of the data (LnP(D)) and the ΔK statistic [41]. CLUMPP was employed to align and consolidate results across replicate runs [41]. Genetic relatedness within populations was assessed using the Kinship model implemented in the GAPIT version 3.0 [42]. The resulting kinship matrix was visualized as a heatmap using ggplot2 and RColorBrewer in R 4.3.3. A neighbor-joining phylogenetic tree was constructed using TASSEL version 5.2.37 [43], and the resulting tree was visualized using the iTOL online platform [44]. Haplotype network analysis was performed using MEGA version 10.0.4 [45] and DnaSP version 6.12.03 [46] for sequence alignment and dataset preparation, with final visualization conducted in POPART [47].

sec.title: SNP-markers distribution and genetic diversity in the collection of 694 soybean accessions
sec.p: The distribution of the 80,971 single SNPs retained after quality control filtering was visualized in 1 Mb windows across the soybean genome (Fig. 1). The corresponding HapMap file for the filtered SNPs is provided in Table S2. A non-uniform distribution of variants was observed across the chromosomes, with an average SNP density of 4,048 per chromosome. The highest SNP density (5,834) was detected on chromosome 18, whereas the lowest density (2,957) was recorded on chromosome 11.

caption.p: Distribution of SNPs within 1 Mb window size across the G. max genome

sec.p: Genetic diversity indices were evaluated for 694 soybean accessions grouped by geographic origin or classification (Table 1).

caption.p: Assessment of the level of genetic diversity of soybean collection based on 80,971 SNPs

table-wrap-foot.p: N – number of accessions, Ne – number of effective alleles, I – Shanon’s index, h – diversity index, uh – unbiased diversity index, MAF – minor allele frequency, PIC – polymorphic index content, π (Pi) – nucleotide diversity, θ (Theta) – Watterson’s theta, D – Tajima’s D

sec.p: The number of accessions (N) ranged from 31 (Kazakhstan) to 211 (Europe), with a mean of 135.98. The number of effective alleles (Ne) varied slightly across groups, with the highest value observed in wild species (1.726) and the lowest in Kazakhstan (1.393). Shannon’s index (I) followed a similar trend, ranging from 0.368 in Kazakhstan to 0.626 in wild species. The diversity index (h) and the unbiased diversity index (uh) also showed variation, with the wild species group exhibiting the highest diversity (h = 0.378, uh = 0.382), while the lowest values were recorded in the Kazakhstan group (h = 0.225, uh = 0.232). Minor allele frequency (MAF) ranged from 0.132 (South America) to 0.211 (wild species). The polymorphic information content (PIC) was highest in wild species (0.378) and lowest in Kazakhstan (0.225). Nucleotide diversity (π) mirrored this pattern, with the wild species showing the highest diversity (0.328) and Kazakhstan having one of the lowest values (0.227). Similarly, Watterson’s theta (θ) was highest in the wild species (9.461E-05) and lowest in North America (7.100E-05). All populations exhibited positive Tajima’s D values, ranging from 0.615 (North America) to 1.303 (Wild species), suggesting a historical reduction in population size, balancing selection, or an excess of intermediate frequency alleles.
The results of FST indices estimation indicated varying degrees of genetic differentiation among the populations (Table 2).

caption.p: Pairwise wright’s fixation indeces (FST) among soybean populations

sec.p: The lowest FST values, suggesting minimal genetic differentiation, were observed between Europe and Kazakhstan (0.011), between Kazakhstan and North America (0.022), and between Europe and North America (0.026), suggesting a relatively close genetic relationship or shared ancestry among these cultivated populations. Conversely, the highest FST values were consistently observed between all cultivated populations and wild species, such as Europe vs. Wild species (0.266), North America vs. Wild species (0.264), and East Asia vs. Wild species (0.256).

AMOVA was performed on a total of 694 soybean accessions, which were divided into populations based on their geographical origin, with G. soja and landraces of G. max forming two distinct individual populations (Table 3). The AMOVA revealed a significant partitioning of genetic variation (P < 0.001). The majority of the total variance (87.69%) was attributed to within-population variation, indicating substantial genetic diversity within individuals in populations. A smaller but significant proportion of the variance (12.31%, P < 0.001) was explained by differences between populations.

caption.p: AMOVA-based partitioning of genetic variance in 694 soybean accessions divided into seven populations

sec.title: Population structure and genetic relatedness in the collection of 694 soybean accessions
sec.p: To assess the genetic structure of the entire soybean panel, PCA was conducted using genome-wide SNP data (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Principal component analysis (PCA) of 694 soybean genotypes based on 80,971 SNP markers

sec.p: The accessions included G. max landraces, modern cultivars from East Asia, Europe, North America, South America, Kazakhstan, and wild soybean (G. soja). The first principal component (PC1) accounts for 44.3% of the total genetic variation, while the second component (PC2) explains 11.7%. The analysis reveals a distinct separation between wild species and cultivated soybean accessions, with landraces forming an intermediate cluster between the wild and improved germplasm. Accessions from East Asia and Europe form relatively compact, though partially overlapping, clusters, while those from Kazakhstan, North America, and South America display broader dispersion.
The phylogenetic analysis of 694 soybean genotypes, based on 80,971 SNP markers, revealed the presence of two distinct clusters (Fig. 3A).

caption.p: Population structure of 694 soybean accessions of different origins. A – phylogenetic tree. The accessions are color-coded according to their geographical origin or taxonomic classification. B – haplotype network. Each node represents a haplotype, with the size of the node proportional to the number of accessions sharing that haplotype

sec.p: Cluster 1 included most of the genotypes, including modern cultivars, breeding lines, and landraces. The grouping of these diverse genotypes into one cluster suggests that, despite their varied origins, they share a closer genetic relationship with each other than with the wild species. Cluster 2 exclusively comprised wild soybean accessions. Grouping these wild genotypes into a single cluster indicates a clear genetic differentiation from the modern cultivated accessions and landraces.

The network analysis revealed a clear bifurcation into two major clusters (Fig. 3B). Cluster 1 comprises all modern cultivars and breeding lines from diverse regions, as well as a substantial group of landraces. Notably, two wild accessions (GDW075 and GDW078) also fall within this cluster, indicating that they share a closer genetic relationship with the cultivated gene pool than other wild genotypes. Cluster 2, in contrast, comprises the majority of wild soybean accessions and one landrace genotype (GDW009), reflecting the substantial genetic divergence between the wild and cultivated forms of soybean. In addition to the two main clusters, the network identifies a set of transitional genotypes that bridge the cultivated and wild gene pools. These include wild accessions (SRR1533211, GDW033, and ZKW0244) and a landrace genotype (GDL015).

Population structure analysis of the 694 soybean genotypes was conducted utilizing a total of 80,971 SNP markers, with the optimal number of populations (K) determined using the Evanno method. Based on ∆K values, the analysis indicated that the 694 soybean genotypes were best represented by two distinct genetic clusters (∆K = 2, Fig. S2). Cluster 1 comprised the entirety of the modern cultivars and lines, including landraces. In contrast, the majority of wild genotypes were assigned to a separate Cluster 2 (Fig. S2). It was noted that five wild species genotypes (GDW058, GDW075, GDW078, ZKW0243, and ZKW0244) were grouped within Cluster 1. Conversely, one accession of European origin (17K2046) and the landrace GDW009 were classified into Cluster 2 (Fig. S2).

To better understand the relationships within cultivated soybean germplasm, further investigation focused on the genetic clustering of landraces and modern cultivars beyond the primary differentiation observed between wild and cultivated soybeans using ∆K-based analysis. For this purpose, four distinct genetic clusters were grouped (Fig. 4).

caption.p: Bar plot of the identified four clusters by Structure and distribution of the collection genotypes is depicted according to origin groups and the color-coded four clusters. A – the distribution of genotypes according to four identified clusters, with color coding corresponding to groups of origin. B – the distribution of genotypes according to seven geographic origin groups, with color coding representing the identified clusters

sec.p: The assignment of accessions to four clusters revealed a distinct pattern of geographical and taxonomic representation. Cluster 1 is predominantly composed of accessions from Europe, as indicated by the largely red segment in its pie chart representation. Cluster 2 exhibited a significant proportion of accessions from East Asia and North America. Cluster 3 was characterized by a strong representation of landraces (light blue) alongside accessions from South America. Finally, Cluster 4 showed a mixed composition, with notable contributions from East Asia and wild species, suggesting a degree of admixture or shared ancestry. These results, derived from the applied four-cluster model, provide a refined perspective on the genetic structure within the cultivated soybean collection.

Genetic relatedness among studied soybean genotypes was also assessed using a kinship model and a refined SNP dataset. A heatmap based on pairwise genetic distances was constructed to visualize the population structure, revealing four distinct genetic clusters (Fig. 5).

caption.p: Kinship heatmap-based genetic clustering of 694 soybean accessions. A – heatmap of pairwise Kinship coefficient with hierarchical clustering. Donut charts indicate the geographic origin composition of each cluster. B – Distribution of accessions across the four genetic clusters within each of the seven geographical origins and taxonomic groups

sec.p: The largest number of genotypes was assigned to Cluster 4, while Cluster 2 contained the fewest (Fig. 5A). Cluster 1 predominantly comprised wild accessions (n = 88), and Cluster 2 mainly included landraces (n = 15), along with several wild, European, and one North American genotype. Cluster 3 was the most diverse, encompassing genotypes from all seven geographic origin groups, especially East Asia (n = 79), Europe (n = 50), South America (n = 51), and landraces (n = 50). Cluster 4 included the majority of European (n = 158) and North American (n = 86) accessions, 29 local genotypes, 66 from East Asia, and one landrace.

Although both the Evanno (ΔK-based) and kinship methods broadly distinguished wild from cultivated soybeans, further analysis was conducted to resolve clustering patterns among landraces and modern cultivars. Both methods identified four clusters, allowing for comparison of genotype distribution patterns.

According to the Evanno method, Cluster 1 consisted mostly of wild species, while the kinship-based approach showed a more mixed composition, including wild, East Asian, and some North American accessions (Fig. 5B). European genotypes were mainly grouped into Cluster 2 by the Evanno method, but appeared across Clusters 2 and 4 in the kinship clustering. Landraces were concentrated in Cluster 4 according to Evanno, but more evenly distributed between Clusters 1 and 3 in the kinship analysis. Kazakh accessions were sparsely distributed in both methods, though their cluster affiliations differed.

Overall, genotype distribution across clusters varied by method. East Asian accessions were largely assigned to Cluster 2 (Evanno), but were more widely distributed in the kinship analysis. European accessions showed similar dispersion. Wild genotypes displayed the most consistent clustering, though the Evanno method indicated slightly greater admixture. Landraces and American accessions showed method-dependent differences, reflecting variability in inferred population structure and genetic relationships.

sec.title: Population structure in the collection of 600 G. max accessions
sec.p: To investigate the genetic relationships among soybean accessions of different geographical origins, a PCA was performed using genome-wide SNP data from 600 G. max accessions only. The first two principal components accounted for 46.5% of the total genetic variation, with PC1 and PC2 explaining 37.2% and 9.3%, respectively (Fig. 6).

The PCA revealed distinct clustering patterns corresponding to the origin of the accessions. Accessions from South America and North America formed relatively tight, separate clusters, indicating strong regional genetic coherence. Kazakhstani accessions were primarily distributed within the cluster of European genotypes, suggesting close genetic relatedness and likely historical exchange of germplasm. East Asian accessions showed broader dispersion, overlapping with both landraces and other regional groups, reflecting their genetic heterogeneity and possible contribution to multiple gene pools. Landraces occupied an intermediate position between groups and showed partial overlap with East Asian, European, and South American accessions, consistent with their role as transitional material in the domestication process.

To assess genetic structure within the soybean collection, a model-based clustering analysis was performed using STRUCTURE, with the optimal number of clusters (K = 3) determined by the Evanno method (Fig. S3). Figure 7 summarizes the inferred population structure and the distribution of accessions among the three clusters.

caption.p: Population structure of 600 soybean accessions based on SNP data. A – STRUCTURE-based clustering results at K = 3, showing individual assignment probabilities to three inferred genetic clusters. Each vertical bar represents an individual accession. Donut plots above the bar graph indicate the geographic origin composition of each cluster. B – Distribution of accessions from each geographic region across the three clusters

sec.p: Cluster 1 was predominantly composed of accessions from East Asia and Europe, while Cluster 2 consisted mainly of South American and landrace accessions, along with a subset from Europe (Fig. 7A). Cluster 3 was enriched for North American genotypes and included most of the Kazakhstan’s accessions. The accompanying donut charts further illustrate the regional composition of each cluster, highlighting distinct geographic patterns. Cluster 1 featured a high proportion of East Asian accessions, Cluster 2 was more geographically mixed, and Cluster 3 showed strong representation from North America and Kazakhstan.

East Asian accessions were mainly assigned to Cluster 1, while South American and landraces were primarily associated with Cluster 2 (Fig. 7B). North American accessions were split between Clusters 1 and 3, whereas most Kazakhstan’s accessions grouped within Cluster 3, reinforcing their close genetic relationship to North American cultivars. European accessions were represented across all three clusters, reflecting a more heterogeneous genetic background.

Hierarchical clustering based on the Kinship matrix revealed the presence of three major genetic clusters among the accessions (Fig. 8A). Cluster 1 formed a well-separated group, while Cluster 2 appeared as a smaller, more genetically homogeneous subcluster. Cluster 3 encompassed a broad range of genetically similar accessions and showed greater internal diversity.

caption.p: Population structure and genetic clustering of accessions based on genomic data. A – Hierarchical clustering heatmap depicting pairwise Kinship coefficients among accessions. B – Bar plot showing the distribution of accessions from different geographical regions across the three genetic clusters

sec.p: The composition of each cluster in terms of geographic origin was visualized using circular plots. Cluster 1 comprised accessions from all regions, with a predominance of European and North American samples, as well as notable representation from landraces. Cluster 2 was primarily composed of European and North American accessions, suggesting a potential shared breeding history or recent divergence. Cluster 3 was more diverse in its geographic composition, featuring a high proportion of East Asian accessions, as well as contributions from Kazakhstan, landraces, and South America.

Together, these results demonstrate a structured pattern of genetic diversity shaped by geographic origin, suggesting the presence of regionally distinct gene pools that potentially reflect domestication history, breeding practices, or environmental adaptation.

sec.title: Genetic diversity and population structure in the collection of 694 G. max and G. soja accessions
sec.p: The high-resolution SNP dataset, comprising 80,971 markers, revealed a non-uniform SNP distribution across the 20 chromosomes of the soybean genome (Fig. 1). Chromosome 18 exhibited the highest SNP density, while chromosome 11 showed the lowest, consistent with previously reported genome-wide variation patterns in soybean [48–50]. Such variation may reflect historical selection pressures and recombination hotspots, with high-density regions facilitating fine mapping and low-density regions highlighting conserved genomic segments critical for core biological functions. Uneven SNP distribution highlights key areas for targeted breeding, as regions with high SNP density facilitate fine mapping and the discovery of causal variants [51], while low-density regions may require deeper genotyping.

Diversity statistics computed for the 694 accessions demonstrated substantial variability across taxonomic and geographic groups. As expected, wild soybean accessions (G. soja) displayed the highest diversity indices – including effective alleles (Ne = 1.726), Shannon’s index (I = 0.626), and polymorphic information content (PIC = 0.378) – due to their broader genetic base and minimal human selection (Table 1). Conversely, cultivated groups showed reduced diversity, particularly those from Kazakhstan (Ne = 1.393, PIC = 0.225), suggesting genetic bottlenecks or founder effects during domestication and regional breeding. The slightly higher nucleotide diversity (π = 0.227) and Tajima’s D (0.723) in Kazakhstan’s accessions (Tables 1 and 2) suggest a degree of retained variation, possibly due to historical introgressions. These findings support previous studies that reported broader genetic variation in wild soybeans due to adaptation to diverse environments [52–54]. In contrast, cultivated groups, especially those from Kazakhstan and North America, showed reduced diversity, likely a consequence of selection during breeding [55].

AMOVA indicated that most genetic variation resides within populations rather than between them (Table 3), a pattern consistent with findings by Hyten et al. (2006) [56], and reflecting high intra-population diversity critical for adaptability.

PCA revealed clear genetic differentiation between wild species and cultivated landraces, with separation along PC1 and clustering along PC2 (Fig. 2). The presence of South American genotypes within the East Asian group suggests historical gene flow, while the proximity of Kazakhstan’s accessions to European and North American genotypes likely reflects shared germplasm and breeding practices.

Population structure analysis using the Evanno method identified two major clusters, representing wild and cultivated soybeans (Fig. S2), which supports phylogenetic and haplotype analyses (Fig. 3). Transitional genotypes (e.g., SRR1533211, GDW033, ZKW0244, and GDL015) bridged these clusters and represent valuable breeding material. Li et al. (2013) [57] emphasized the potential of such genotypes to introduce traits like stress tolerance and disease resistance into cultivated lines.

Comparison of clustering methods revealed minor discrepancies: the Evanno method identified Cluster 2 as the largest (Fig. 5), while the Kinship model indicated Cluster 4 (Fig. 4). Such differences underscore the need to carefully select analytical methods, as highlighted by Frankham et al. (2010) [58]. Nonetheless, wild soybeans consistently formed Cluster 1 across both models, confirming their genetic distinctness and relevance for breeding [54, 59]. Transitional genotypes identified in Cluster 2 (Kinship model) further illustrate the genetic continuum between wild and cultivated forms [60], offering unique alleles for crop improvement.

Kazakh accessions clustered closely with Chinese genotypes, reflecting historical germplasm exchange. Soybeans were introduced into Kazakhstan in the early 20th century from Manchuria, a region renowned for its rich soybean diversity [25]. This early introduction influenced breeding programs in the USSR and shaped the genetic composition of modern Kazakh soybean lines. As East Asia, particularly China, is the center of soybean domestication [48], shared ancestry and selection for temperate adaptation likely explain the observed genetic affinities. This historical background provides context for the population structure results, emphasizing East Asia’s central role in shaping soybean genetic diversity.

sec.title: Genetic diversity and population structure of kazakhstan’s soybean accessions in a global G. max collection
sec.p: The analysis of the genetic structure and diversity within a global panel of 600 cultivated soybean (G. max) accessions revealed clear population stratification associated with geographic origin and breeding history. PCA, STRUCTURE-based clustering, and hierarchical clustering based on a kinship matrix consistently identified three main genetic clusters, providing insights into the phylogenetic relationships and regional differentiation of the germplasm collection.

Kazakhstan’s accessions were predominantly positioned within or adjacent to the European cluster in the PCA plot (Fig. 6), reflecting close genetic proximity and suggesting shared ancestry or historical germplasm exchange. This pattern aligns with earlier findings based on a smaller set of 113 accessions genotyped with 4,442 SNPs [5, 61], reinforcing the notion that Kazakhstan’s soybean cultivars are derived from or influenced by European breeding material. Notably, the PCA also revealed partial overlap between Kazakhstani genotypes and those from North America, suggesting a broader connection with temperate-region gene pools.

STRUCTURE analysis at K = 3 (Fig. 7A) further clarified population differentiation. Most Kazakhstan’s accessions were assigned to Cluster 3, which also included a substantial proportion of North American genotypes. This cluster exhibited a relatively narrow genetic base compared to Clusters 1 and 2, indicating that Kazakhstani accessions may represent a subset of a more homogenous gene pool, possibly shaped by recent breeding efforts. These findings are consistent with previous studies using SSR markers in global soybean collections [62], which also revealed genetic affinities among Kazakhstani, European, and North American genotypes.

Hierarchical clustering using pairwise kinship coefficients (Fig. 8A) supported the STRUCTURE results, showing that Kazakhstan’s accessions predominantly grouped within Cluster 3. The corresponding geographic distribution (Fig. 8B) showed that this cluster is enriched with North American cultivars and includes contributions from Kazakhstan and South America. Although a few Kazakhstan’s accessions were found in Clusters 1 and 2, the majority formed a coherent group within Cluster 3, reinforcing their strong relatedness to modern North American breeding lines. Despite their broad geographic affiliations, the overall genetic diversity among Kazakhstan’s accessions appeared limited, consistent with the narrow clustering observed across multiple analyses. This restricted diversity suggests a limited genetic base, likely stemming from a relatively short breeding history and dependence on imported cultivars. The observed genetic proximity to European and North American germplasm suggests potential vulnerability to shared biotic and abiotic stresses, highlighting the need to incorporate more diverse materials into local breeding programs [63].

To enhance adaptability and resilience, the introduction of novel alleles from genetically divergent populations, such as East Asian landraces or wild relatives, should be prioritized. These gene pools harbor traits related to disease resistance, abiotic stress tolerance, and improved seed quality, which could help broaden the genetic base and mitigate inbreeding risks. Strategic hybridization and introgression from genetically distant sources can support the development of robust, high-yielding soybean varieties adapted to Kazakhstan’s unique agro-climatic conditions.

In conclusion, while Kazakhstani soybean accessions exhibit close genetic relationships with cultivars from Europe and North America, their limited diversity emphasizes the urgency of expanding the breeding gene pool. These accessions nonetheless represent valuable regional resources, and their targeted use in breeding could contribute to the sustainable development of soybean cultivation in Central Asia.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This comprehensive genomic study of 694 soybean accessions, integrating Kazakhstani genotypes into a global context, provides valuable insights into the population structure, genetic diversity, and evolutionary relationships of G. max. Using 80,971 high-quality SNP markers, the analysis revealed that Kazakhstani accessions are genetically closest to European and North American cultivars, reflecting a legacy of shared breeding histories and adaptation to temperate agro-ecological conditions. However, this genetic proximity also underscores a limited diversity within the Kazakhstan’s germplasm pool, as evidenced by the lowest values in diversity indices and a narrow clustering pattern across multiple analytical methods. The restricted genetic base of Kazakhstan’s accessions signals potential vulnerability to regionally shared biotic and abiotic stresses. This finding underscores the crucial need to expand the local breeding pool through the strategic introduction of genetically distant materials, particularly from East Asian landraces and wild relatives (G. soja), which harbor unique alleles associated with stress tolerance and yield stability. Such introgression efforts could significantly enhance the resilience, adaptability, and productivity of future cultivars in Kazakhstan’s variable environments. Ultimately, Kazakhstan’s soybean accessions, despite their limited diversity, represent an important regional gene pool with strong agronomic potential. Their characterization lays a solid foundation for modern breeding initiatives that aim to combine local adaptation with globally sourced genetic innovations, thereby contributing to sustainable soybean production in Central Asia and beyond.

sec.p: Below is the link to the electronic supplementary material.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors acknowledge Professor Fanjiang Kong from the Department of Life Science at Ganzhou University for his invaluable contribution to this study. We deeply appreciate his efforts in resequencing our soybean collection and providing the genotyping information essential for our analysis.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: YT and SA conceived and designed the project. AZ, YG, and CF performed the experiments. AZ, YG, SA, and CF curated and analysed data. AZ, YG, and YT have prepared the draft of the manuscript.YT and CF supervised the project and revised the manuscript.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: The research was funded by the Committee of Science of the Ministry of Science and Higher Education of the Republic of Kazakhstan (Program No BR24992903).

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: Raw resequencing data of 252 soybean accessions are available at zenodo.org, DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.15392468. Resequencing data of 442 accessions were obtained from the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under the following accession numbers: SRP469369, SRP114890, SRP250886, SRP387668, SRP326758, and SRP344122. Other datasets generated during and/or analyzed during the current study are available in the Additional Files.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
